results.title: India to consider engaging in development projects in Afghanistan
results.body:
NEW DELHI: India will consider engaging in development projects in Afghanistan in the near future, India's Foreign Ministry said on Wednesday, despite the lack of diplomatic relations.

The statement followed a meeting between Indian Foreign Secretary Vikram Misri and Afghanistan's Acting Foreign Minister Mawlawi Amir Khan Muttaqi in Dubai.

"In response to the request from the Afghan side, India will provide further material support in the first instance to the health sector and for the rehabilitation of refugees," the statement said.

India has so far dispatched several shipments consisting of wheat, medicines, COVID vaccines, and winter clothing to Afghanistan.

India does not recognise the Taliban government which seized power in 2021 and closed its own embassy in Kabul after the Taliban took control that year.

Afghanistan's embassy in New Delhi was closed in November 2023 after diplomats appointed by the Afghan government ousted by the Taliban failed to secure visa extensions from their Indian hosts.

results.title: Insec pests of Sorghum and their effective management.
results.body:
FIELD REPORT THAT AIMS THE DIAGNOSIS AND EFFECTIVE

MANAGEMENT OF INSECTICIDE TO CONTROL SHOOT FLY

AND STEM BORER IN SORGHUM PLANT

1.0 Introduction

This introductory considered the

background, objective, scope and research

questions dealing with the study of diagnosis

and management of insect pests of Sorghum.

1.1 Background of the study

Sorghum, a resilient crop cultivated globally,

faces a range of insect pests that can

significantly impact its yield and quality.

Effective management of these pests requires a

thorough understanding of their biology,

behavior, and the damage they cause.

Sorghum is a vital crop in Africa, particularly

in arid and semi-arid regions where other

cereals struggle. It provides food security for

millions, serving as a staple food and livestock

feed. Its resilience to drought and heat stress

makes it an adaptable crop for challenging

environments.

Sorghum cultivation in Somalia is a cornerstone

of the country's agricultural sector, particularly

in rainfed areas. Local varieties are well-

adapted to the challenging climate and play a

crucial role in food security and livelihoods.

Farmers rely on traditional knowledge and

practices passed down through generations to

cultivate sorghum, often integrating it with

livestock farming in agro-pastoralist systems.

1.2 Objectives of the study

General objectives

 To assess the current status of insect pest

infestations in Sorghum plant.

 To develop and evaluate effective and

sustainable insect pest managents

insecticide for Sorghum.

Specific Objectives

 To identify the major insect pests aaffecting

Sorghum plant.

 To determine the distribution and

abundance of key insect pests throughout

the growing season.

 To assess the level of

damage caused by different

insect pests on Sorghum.

1.3 Scope of the study

The importance of diagnosing

and managing insect pests in

Sorghum crop. The goals of

the field report, including

early detection, accurate

diagnosis, and effective

management of insecticides.

Techniques for identifying

insect pests based on visual

symptoms, damage patterns,

and insect morphology. The

description of common

symptoms caused by insect

pests, such as leaf damage,

head damage, and deadheart.

The use of insecticide, visual

inspections, and sampling

techniques to monitor insect

populations in the field. This whole study was a

month. I spent two weeks diagnosis, then two

weeks controlling with pesticides. Finally, I

spent another two weeks checking how well the

pesticide worked "mode of action", if it caused

any effective, and how it affected the insects.

This study was conducted in the research and

practice fields of Somali National University,

for faculty of agriculture and environmental

science, it was actually about a month, this

study was semester assignment that submitted

to Mr. Hussain Ahmed Nur one of the lectures

of Somali National University at faculty of

agriculture and environmental science.

1.4 Questions of the study

 What are the most major insect pests

currently infesting Sorghum plants?

 What is the most effective insecticide

used to control insect pests of Sorghum?

2.0 Literature review

2.1 Sorghum plant:

Sorghum is a versatile and resilient

cereal grain that is cultivated for food, fodder,

and industrial purposes. It is a member of the

grass family and thrives in arid and semi-arid

regions due to its drought tolerance. Sorghum

grains are used in a variety of food products,

including porridge, bread, and beverages.

Additionally, sorghum stalks are used for

animal feed and biofuel production, making it a

valuable crop for both subsistence and

commercial agriculture.

Sorghum is widely distributed across

the globe, with significant cultivation in regions

such as Africa, Asia, and the Americas. The

United States, India, Nigeria, and Mexico are

among the top producers of sorghum. In these

regions, sorghum is grown primarily for grain

production and animal feed. The crop's ability

to withstand harsh environmental conditions

makes it an important staple in areas prone to

drought and food scarcity. Sorghum's

adaptability has also led to its use in the production of gluten-free foods and alcoholic

beverages.

Africa is the largest producer of

sorghum, with countries like Nigeria, Sudan,

and Ethiopia leading in cultivation. Sorghum is

a crucial food crop in many African countries,

providing a primary source of calories for

millions of people. It is often grown in areas

where other cereals, such as maize and wheat,

struggle to thrive. In addition to its use as a

food staple, sorghum is also used for brewing

traditional beers and spirits. The crop's

resilience to drought and poor soil conditions

makes it a reliable choice for farmers across the

continent.

In Somalia,

sorghum is an essential

crop for both food security

and economic livelihood. It

is primarily grown in the

southern regions of the country, where it serves

as a staple food for the population. Sorghum is

used to make traditional Somali dishes such as

"anjera" (a type of flatbread) and porridge. The

crop's ability to grow in dry, arid conditions

makes it particularly suited to Somalia's

climate. Additionally, sorghum cultivation

supports the livelihoods of many smallholder

farmers,

contributing to the

country's

agricultural sector

and food self-

sufficiency.

2.2 Shoot fly

The Sorghum shoot fly (Atherigona

soccata) is a small fly that resembles a

housefly. The adult female lays eggs on the

underside of sorghum leaves, and the larvae

hatch and burrow into the growing shoot,

causing significant damage. The larvae feed on

the central growing point, leading to the death

of the shoot and resulting in a condition known

as "deadheart"

Infestation typically occurs in young plants,

making them stunted and unproductive. The

damage is most severe during the seedling

stage, but can also affect older plants under

high humidity conditions. The presence of

shoot fly can lead to reduced yields and poor

crop quality, making it a significant pest for

sorghum farmers.

Management strategies include cultural

practices such as adjusting planting times, using

resistant varieties, and applying appropriate

insecticides. Biological control methods, such

as introducing natural predators, can also help

reduce shoot fly populations. Integrated pest

management (IPM) approaches are

recommended to effectively control this pest

while minimizing environmental impact.

Taxonomic rank

 Domain: Eukaryota

 Kingdom: Animalia

 Phylum: Arthropoda

 Class: Insecta

 Order: Diptera

 Family: Muscidae

 Genus: Atherigona

Species: Atherigona soccata

2.3 Stem borer

Stem borers (Chilo partellus) are a major pest

of sorghum, attacking the plant at various

stages of growth. They lay eggs on the leaves,

and the larvae hatch and bore into the stems,

feeding on the inner tissues. This can cause

significant damage to the plant, including

stunted growth, deadhearts, and lodging.

The life cycle of a stem borer typically involves

four stages: egg, larva, pupa, and adult. The

eggs are laid on the leaves of the host plant, and

the larvae hatch and bore into the stems. The

larvae feed on the inner tissues of the stem,

causing damage to the plant. Once the larvae

are fully grown, they pupate inside the stem.

The adult moths emerge from the pupae and lay

eggs, starting the cycle again.

Several management strategies can be

used to control stem borers in sorghum. These

include cultural practices such as crop rotation,

planting resistant varieties, and timely planting.

Chemical control can also be used, but it is

important to use insecticides carefully to avoid

harming beneficial insects. Biological control

methods, such as the use of natural enemies of

stem borers, can also be effective.

Taxonomic rank

 Domain: Eukaryota

 Kingdom: Animalia

 Phylum: Arthropoda

 Class: Insecta

 Order: Lepidoptera

 Family: Crambidae

 Genus: Chilo

 Species: C. partellus

3.0 Research methods

I used note book as data collection method, in a

field of Sorghum there was huge number of

plants I selected the damaged plants as sample,

I noted all damage symptoms and names of

larvae and adult insect that was in a field.

Instead of images of damages and insects I

captured by using my cellphone as data

collection sample, and also I used the phone to identify the type of insect and damage caused

by insects. Finally when I recognized,

diagnosed and identified the damage of insects

and types of insects that caused these damage

symptoms. I decided and recommended using

three of two of insecticides and mixing together

by ratio of 15:10, these insecticides was protect

plus and power side.

4.0 Discussion and results

4.1 Results

This study has become evident that the

use of the two pesticides Protect plus and

Power side are effective in controlling the two

pests that I have previously mentioned. This

investigation and control took me 28 days to

determine the results after spraying the

pesticide. It became clear to me that the use of

these pesticides is effective in controlling these

two pests. I recommend that people farming in

Sorghum these pesticides if they find these

pests in their farms. I found that the two

pesticides that I used worked really well to get

rid of the pests. It took me a month to see the

results, but the pesticides were very effective. I

suggest that farmers in Sorghum to use these

pesticides if they have the same pests like Shoot

fly, and stem borer.

4.2 Discussion

Data collection: notebook as data

collection method- notebooks are a reliable way

to record observations in the field. They allow

for flexibility in recording different types of

data and can be easily reviewed later, Selection

of damaged plants: focusing on damaged plants

is a good way to identify the specific insects

causing the damage. However, it's also

important to sample healthy plants to get a

baseline understanding of what a healthy

sorghum plant looks like, Recording symptoms

and insects- noting both damage symptoms and

the insects found on the plants is crucial for

accurate identification and diagnosis, using

phone for images- photos can be a valuable

addition to written observations.

They provide visual documentation of

the damage and insects, which can be helpful

for identification and future reference, Using

phone for insect identification-

there are many

insect identification apps and online resources

available that can help you identify the insects

you found. This can be a valuable tool, but it's

important to double-check identifications with a

knowledgeable entomologist if possible,

Management strategies: mixing insecticides-

mixing insecticides can be a risky strategy, as it

can increase the likelihood of environmental

contamination and pesticide resistance. It's

generally recommended to use a single

insecticide at a time, following the label

instructions carefully, Ratio of insecticides- the

ratio (15:10 ml). It's important to carefully read

the label instructions for both insecticides to

ensure they are compatible and to determine the

correct mixing ratio.

5.0 Conclusion

his study highlights the importance of

diagnosing and managing insect pests in

sorghum crops. The goals included early

detection, accurate diagnosis, and effective

insecticide management. The research involved

identifying pests through visual symptoms,

damage patterns, and insect morphology.

Common pest symptoms included leaf damage,

head damage, and "deadheart." Monitoring

techniques included visual inspections and

sampling to assess pest populations.

The study spanned a month, divided

into three phases: two weeks of diagnosing

pests, two weeks of pesticide application, and

two weeks evaluating pesticide effectiveness.

Two pesticides, Protect Plus and Power Side,

were tested against shoot fly and stem borer

pests. Results showed these pesticides were

highly effective, with noticeable pest control

achieved within 28 days after application.

The study recommends farmers use

these pesticides for effective management of

similar pests in sorghum fields. The findings

emphasize the importance of a structured

approach to pest management, combining early

detection, precise diagnosis, and strategic

pesticide use.

6.0 Recommendations

 Conduct regular field inspections to

identify insect presence early.

 Use sampling techniques like sweep

nets, sticky traps, and direct visual

observation.

 Promote research on alternative pest

control methods, including organic

options.

 Develop guidelines tailored to local pest

challenges and environmental

conditions.

 Combine cultural practices (crop

rotation, planting resistant varieties)

with biological controls.

 Use chemical insecticides only when

necessary to minimize resistance

buildup.

 Monitor pest populations post-

application to assess the mode of action

and effectiveness of the insecticides.

 Record any unintended effects on non-

target organisms or crop health.

results.title: Crops affect pasture CAUV - Farm and Dairy
results.body:
Let's start today's article with a question. How can corn, soybeans and wheat affect Ohio's pastures?

The answer is through the Current Agriculture Use Value. In Ohio, CAUV is governed by the Department of Taxation in each county's auditor's office. In 1972, Ohio voters approved a constitutional amendment to create CAUV. It was designed to help farmers by offering a value that would typically be below the true market value of the land, resulting in a lower tax bill. To qualify, a landowner must have 10 or more acres devoted exclusively to commercial agricultural use. If under 10 acres are devoted exclusively to commercial agricultural use, the farm must produce an average yearly gross income of at least $2,500.

When determining the value of agricultural land, soil type is also taken into consideration with approximately 3,500 map units of soil that have a slope of 25% or less.

As it relates to pasture, the Ohio Department of Taxation reads, "Where soil map units listed in these tables or comparable soils are used for permanent pasture, they should be valued as cropland." However, those pastures that do have a slope greater than 25% will report as the minimum which is $230 per acre (woodlands are also valued at the minimum).

CAUV is based on five different factors, including cropping patterns. The tax commissioner calculates the total number of corn, soybeans and wheat acres that have been planted to get a percentage. They then take a five-year average from those crops to achieve the crop pattern for Ohio.

Crop price comes from the past seven years of data with the highest and lowest prices eliminated. Then the remaining five-year prices are averaged. Crop yields are calculated by the 10-year average from the USDA regarding crop yields.

Non-land production cost is data on crop productions used to estimate average non-land production costs. The data is taken from the Ohio Crop Production Budgets prepared by the Ohio State University College of Food, Agricultural and Environmental Sciences.

And finally, the capitalization rate is calculated by the past seven years of data with the highest and lowest interest rates eliminated. Then the remaining five-year prices are averaged. The interest rates come for Farm Credit Service.

As mentioned earlier, there are different values for over 3,500 different soil types. These values are called the productivity index or how likely the land is going to be able to produce crops. These values are determined by an ag advisory committee and sent to the Ohio Department of Taxation to finalize. Once finalized, it is sent to county auditors to record the calculations based on your property's soil type.

Here is a quick breakdown of these calculations once the productivity index number is established. Gross operating income (GOI) is found by taking the crop yield multiplied by average crop price (GOI = crop yield x average crop price). Net operating income (NOI) is found by GOI minus nonland production cost (NOI = GOI - non-land production costs). Finally, CAUV value is taking that NOI divided by the capitalization rate (CAUV value = NOI/capitalization rate).

If you were to look at the breakdown of the agricultural use of your property, it would show what soil type is in a parcel, how many acres of that soil type and what the agricultural value is of that property. You must file for CAUV every year before the first Monday in March at your local auditors' office.

results.title: Syrians breathe free but millions remain displaced
results.body:
There was a breath of fresh air in Syria as a newly liberated population ushered in the New Year with celebrations in downtown Damascus.

This was the first new year's celebration in 50 years without a member of the Assad family in power.

But as the country gradually comes to grips with a new post-Assad reality, the situation on the ground for many Syrians remains dreadful.

Syrian investigative journalist Mohammed Bassiki, founder of Siraj, an investigative reporting organisation, tells MaltaToday the situation is "catastrophic", especially in the refugee camps.

"Millions of internally displaced Syrians remain in dire need of food and medical aid and many continue to live in refugee camps, particularly in northwestern Syria, which was a stronghold of armed opposition forces," Bassiki says.

He speaks to this newspaper at the turn of the year, just three weeks after the fall of the Assad regime at the hands of opposition forces led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham.

He notes that the new transitional government has received support and messages of endorsement from various Arab countries, particularly the wealthy Gulf states. But of note is the pledge made by Ukraine, which is still trying to push back a three-year-old Russian invasion.

"Ukraine, a new ally of the government, has pledged 500 tonnes of wheat as humanitarian aid following the cessation of Russian supplies," Bassiki says, adding Ukraine announced the resumption of diplomatic ties with Syria.

Russia was a key ally of Assad, propping up the regime with weapons and assistance. Russia also has two military bases in Syria, including a maritime base which gives it direct access to the Mediterranean.

Bassiki says the past few weeks have uncovered the magnitude of the atrocities perpetrated by the regime to suppress opposition and dissent.

"The collapse of the regime and Bashar al-Assad's escape revealed horrifying cases of detainees in former regime-controlled prisons, especially the infamous Sednaya Prison and other Syrian intelligence facilities," he says.

On the security front, he notes that the new Syrian government has begun restructuring internal security, appointing a new head of Syrian intelligence. Meanwhile, armed opposition forces are pursuing remnants of regime forces in remaining pockets along Syria's coastal areas, which had been a recruitment base for regime fighters throughout the Syrian revolution.

There have been multiple calls from various quarters within Syria for the new government to be inclusive. The country is a complex tapestry of different religions and ethnicities.

"Concerns about the potential exclusion of Syria's minority groups in the new regime have been continuously denied by the new administration's leader, Ahmad al-Sharaa," Bassiki says, noting that an inclusive Syrian government is a prerequisite for Western recognition and the eventual lifting of European and American sanctions.

But hope is being pinned on a what is being called a national dialogue conference that is expected to be held in the coming days. Bassiki says the conference will bring around 1,200 representatives from across Syria together to form a committee responsible for managing the next phase.

"This may include the potential dissolution of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, the suspension of the former parliament (People's Assembly), and the suspension of the existing constitution," he says.

As Syrians navigate the new waters ahead, there is hope that after 13 years of civil war a different country can be born; a country that for the first time in half century is able to breathe free even if the air is heavy with suffering.

results.body:
Who Is Geetu Mohandas: From Best Child Artist To Acclaimed Director Of Yash's Highly Anticipated 'Toxic'

In a first, India and Taliban engaged in high-level bilateral talks in Dubai, as Foreign Secretary Vikram Misri met with the Afghanistan's acting Foreign Minister Mawlawi Amir Khan Muttaqi on Wednesday. The meeting highlighted New Delhi's commitment to addressing Afghanistan's urgent development needs. Misri also received an assurance from Muttaqi that Afghan territory would not be used against India.

The meeting signals a major shift in India's approach towards Kabul since the Taliban took over in 2021. Earlier, Indian officials at the Joint Secretary level had met with Taliban ministers, including Amir Khan Muttaqi and Defence Minister Mohammad Yaqoob. However, Foreign Secretary Vikram Misri's discussion represents a significant upgrade in engagement.

"In view of the current need for development activities, it was decided that India would consider engaging in development projects in the near future, in addition to the ongoing humanitarian assistance programme," read a statement issued by the MEA.

The Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) announced that both sides agreed to boost the use of Chabahar Port to support trade, commercial activities, and humanitarian assistance for Afghanistan.

The meeting in Dubai occurred amid growing tensions between Afghanistan and Pakistan. Afghanistan's ties with Islamabad have worsened due to Pakistan Taliban activities and retaliatory airstrikes on Afghan soil. India expressed solidarity with Afghanistan earlier this week, criticizing Pakistan for blaming its neighbors for internal issues. The meeting came two days after India condemned Pakistan's recent airstrikes, which killed 46 people, including women and children.

"We have noted the media reports on airstrikes on Afghan civilians, including women and children, in which several precious lives have been lost," said MEA spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal.

"We unequivocally condemn any attack on innocent civilians. It is an old practice of Pakistan to blame its neighbours for its own internal failures. We have also noted the response of an Afghan spokesperson in this regard," he added.

On December 24, Pakistani airstrikes in Afghanistan killed 46 people, drawing heavy criticism and a strong warning from Afghanistan's current government.

The strikes, carried out by Pakistani fighter jets, hit civilian areas in Barmal district, Paktika province. This marked the second such attack in 2024, following a similar strike in March that killed eight, including three children.

According to a statement by Ministry of External Affairs, the Foreign Secretary emphasized India's long-standing friendship with the Afghan people and strong people-to-people ties. He highlighted India's commitment to addressing Afghanistan's urgent development needs. The two sides also discussed boosting sports cooperation, particularly in cricket, which is popular among Afghanistan's youth.

During discussions on ongoing humanitarian aid, the Afghan Minister expressed gratitude to India for its continued support.

In response to Afghanistan's needs, India has sent several shipments, including 50,000 MT of wheat, 300 tonnes of medicines, 27 tonnes of earthquake relief, 40,000 litres of pesticides, 100 million polio vaccine doses, 1.5 million Covid vaccine doses, 11,000 drug rehabilitation kits, 500 winter clothing units, and 1.2 tonnes of stationery.

results.title: GRAINS-Chicago soybeans dip on stronger dollar, easing Argentina...
results.body:
By Ella Cao and Mei Mei Chu

BEIJING, Jan 9 (Reuters) - Chicago soybean futures slipped on Thursday, pressured by a stronger U.S. dollar and easing concerns over dryness in key exporter Argentina, while investors looked for more clarity on U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's tariff plans.

Corn rose as traders repositioned ahead of a U.S. Department of Agriculture crop report on Friday, while wheat gained after purchases from South Korea.

The most-active soybean contract on the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) was down 0.28% at $9.92 a bushel, as of 0357 GMT, while corn edged up 0.11% to $4.54-4/8 a bushel.

The U.S. dollar charged ahead on rising bond yields, following a report that Trump was considering the use of emergency measures to allow for a new tariff programme.

A stronger dollar makes U.S. grains more expensive for buyers holding other currencies, thus less competitive overseas.

Traders were awaiting the U.S. crop data for supply and demand insights.

Agricultural consultant Andrew Whitelaw of Episode 3 in Canberra noted that while the USDA report could prompt some market repositioning ahead, "a tight, range-bound market" was expected.

Market players were also monitoring weather developments in key South American growing regions, with rain forecasts for Argentina in mid-January dispelling dryness worries.

In Brazil, dry weather is limiting soybean development in the southernmost state, while heavy rains may disrupt early harvests in central regions, according to meteorologists.

Despite this, Brazil is anticipating a bumper soybean harvest. StoneX forecast Brazil's soybean production to reach 171.4 million metric tons in 2024/25, a 14.4% increase from the previous season.

"Argentina is dry, but unless major problems emerge in Brazil, the total South American crop is expected to be enough to keep global supplies elevated," Bergman Grains Research said in a note.

The most-active wheat contract rose 0.23% to $5.38 a bushel.

Purchases from South Korean feedmakers lent support to the market, even as cheaper supplies from Argentina and the Black Sea region weighed on prices.

China will accelerate the breeding of new soybean and corn varieties and prioritise yield improvements for key grains and oil crops, as part of broad efforts to ensure food security, the agriculture ministry said late on Wednesday.

(Reporting by Ella Cao and Mei Mei Chu; Editing by Sumana Nandy and Subhranshu Sahu)
